If a product does not contain runtime.compatibility.auth, then there is a scary looking NoClassDefFoundError in the log on every startup.  We shouldn't be logging an exception here since it's perfectly reasonable for an application to not have the runtime compatibility fragment.  For example, p2 has several applications that fit into this category and we see this stack trace all the time.

!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.runtime 2 0 2007-11-30 14:40:55.328
!MESSAGE Authorization infrastructure (org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.auth) not installed.
!STACK 0
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.auth.AuthorizationHandler
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.initializeAuthorizationHandler(InternalPlatform.java:603)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.start(InternalPlatform.java:745)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.PlatformActivator.start(PlatformActivator.java:31)
	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContextImpl$2.run(BundleContextImpl.java:999)
...

Created an attachment (id=84229)
Proposed fix

The exception is actually logged in two places. It is logged on startup, and it is logged each time a client calls Platform API that requires the auth fragment. This patch avoids logging on startup, but still logs in the case where a client uses the auth API and it's not available. We can't obscure this failure because it might indicate a real problem for clients/users.  If the auth fragment is missing but nobody ever tries to use it, then there is no problem.
